questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents with complaints of a mass near his groin. Examination reveals a 4 cm-sized oval swelling above the right inguinal ligament, medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for this condition?

choices.text: Persistence of a patent processus vaginalis
Protrusion of viscus through the femoral ring
Acquired weakness of the abdominal wall
Protrusion of viscus through the linea alba

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a 65-year-old man presenting with a 4-cm oval swelling above the right inguinal ligament is suggestive of an inguinal hernia. The swelling is medial to the inferior epigastric vessels which is suggestive of a direct inguinal hernia. The most probable underlying cause of a direct inguinal hernia is an acquired weakness of the abdominal wall. 

Direct inguinal hernia is common in elderly patients through the area of the Hesselbach’s triangle. It occurs as a result of acquired weakening and stretching of the abdominal wall. This area of the wall is weak as it consists of only the transversalis fascia covered by the external oblique aponeurosis. 

The contents of a direct hernia protrude outward, forward, and medial to the inferior epigastric artery and the deep inguinal ring (in comparison to the contents of an indirect hernia which protrudes lateral to the inferior epigastric artery). A Lichtenstein mesh repair is currently one of the most frequently used methods for treating an inguinal hernia. It is an elective reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults which consists of an anterior tension-free mesh repair that reduces the chances of recurrence of a hernia. A piece of prosthetic nonabsorbable mesh is used to bridge the defect in this repair.

Other options:
Option A: Persistence of a patent processus vaginalis is the underlying cause of an indirect inguinal hernia. The sac of an indirect inguinal hernia passes from the internal inguinal ring obliquely towards the external inguinal ring and then reaches the scrotum.

Option B: Protrusion of the viscus through the femoral ring is the underlying cause of a femoral hernia that is more commonly seen in elderly females. It presents as a swelling below the inguinal ligament, and lateral to the pubic tubercle.

Option D: Protrusion of viscus through the linea alba is the underlying cause of a paraumbilical hernia, located slightly around the umbilicus.

Related Pearl: Boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle

  • Lateral - inferior epigastric artery
  • Medial - lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferior - inguinal ligament

Direct inguinal hernia emerges through Hesselbach’s triangle (Hence situated medial to inferior epigastric artery)

Indirect inguinal hernia enters deep inguinal ring (Hence it is lateral to inferior epigastric artery)

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient presents with complaints of lower back pain and abdominal fullness. Examination reveals a palpable, expansile, and non-tender midline abdominal mass at the level of the umbilicus. Which of the following is an important risk factor for the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of an elderly 68-year-old male patient presenting with complaints of lower back pain, and examination findings of an expansile, and non-tender midline abdominal mass at the level of the umbilicus is suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Cigarette smoking is one of the most important modifiable risk factors for the development of this condition.

Abdominal aortic aneurysms are mostly asymptomatic and are detected as incidental findings on investigations for other complaints. However, as the aneurysm expands, patients may present with lower back or abdominal pain and an associated pulsatile abdominal mass (like seen in this patient). 

These aneurysms present more frequently in males than females and their incidence increases with age. An important underlying cause for the development of this condition is atherosclerosis. Smoking is considered one of the strongest risk factors for the development of this condition. 

Abdominal ultrasound is a useful initial test for screening. CT abdomen with contrast is the preferred investigation of choice to determine the location and size of the aneurysm, which helps guide further management. 

Rupture of the aneurysm is a dreaded complication and usually presents with shock and hypotension. It usually occurs when the size of the aneurysm is more than 5.5 cm. 

Other options:
Options A and B: Connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome and a history of untreated syphilis causing tertiary syphilis are important risk factors for thoracic aortic aneurysms.

Option C: Previous abdominal surgery does not increase the risk of aortic aneurysm.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with complaints of fever, hematuria, and an abdominal mass. Examination reveals a right-sided, ballotable flank mass, which is smooth, firm, and non-tender on palpation and does not cross the midline. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a 4-year-old child presenting with fever, hematuria, and a ballotable, unilateral flank mass, which is smooth, and non-tender is suggestive of a nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor).

Wilms tumor is the most common primary malignant renal tumor in children and is the second most common malignant abdominal tumor in children. The clinical presentation usually involves an asymptomatic abdominal mass, hypertension, abdominal pain, and gross painless hematuria. Constitutional symptoms of fever, anorexia, and weight loss can also be present at the time of diagnosis. Thrombus from the tumor extends into the inferior vena cava (IVC) in 4–10% of patients and may produce a fatal pulmonary embolism.

The tumor arises due to loss of function mutation of the WT1 (Wilm's tumor 1) gene. Noteworthy associated syndromes and their features include:

  • WAGR syndrome: Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary abnormalities, mental retardation
  • Denys-Drash syndrome: Early-onset renal failure, gonadal dysgenesis / male pseudohermaphroditism
  • Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome: Hemihypertrophy, organomegaly, macroglossia

Diagnosis involves imaging studies such as USG Abdomen with Doppler for evaluation of the collecting system and to look for tumor thrombi in renal veins and inferior vena cava. CECT abdomen is used to identify the extent of the disease, to access the contralateral kidney, and for metastasis. Management is surgical and involves a radical or partial nephrectomy, according to patient presentation.

Other options:
Option B: Neuroblastoma is also commonly seen in children of preschool age. Affected children commonly present with a palpable, irregular abdominal mass that is large and may cross the midline. It presents with associated clinical features of gastrointestinal/genitourinary obstruction, diarrhea, skin nodules, and characteristic paraneoplastic symptoms ("raccoon eyes," myoclonus-opsoclonus).

Option C: Renal cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the kidney in adults. It usually occurs in the age group 50-70 years. It is unlikely to be the cause of this child's renal mass and symptoms.

Option D: Hepatoblastoma would present as a right upper quadrant mass and jaundice in children below 3 years of age. It is unlikely to present as a ballotable flank mass, as seen in this case.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with complaints of fever, intermittent periumbilical pain, and nausea for the past 2 days. Abdominal examination reveals an ill-defined mass in the right iliac fossa which is very tender to palpation. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 25-year-old patient presenting with fever, intermittent periumbilical pain, nausea, and a tender and ill-defined mass in the right iliac fossa is suggestive of an appendicular mass. The best next step in the management of this patient is conservative management with the Ochsner–Sherren regimen which includes intravenous antibiotics and analgesics.

An appendicular mass may develop following acute appendicitis when the greater omentum and loops of the small bowel become adherent to the inflamed appendix to wall off the spread of peritoneal contamination, resulting in a phlegmonous mass or paracaecal abscess. 

CT scan of the abdomen is necessary for diagnosis and to know about the initial size of the appendicular mass. The management for an appendicular mass is conservative with the Ochsner–Sherren regimen. This is based on the fact that the inflammatory process is already localized and surgery may be dangerous. It may be very difficult to locate the appendix and surgical complications like fecal fistula are a concern. For these reasons, the immediate management is non-operative. Surgical intervention is reserved for clinical deterioration.

The Ochsner–Sherren regimen comprises hospitalization, intravenous fluids, antibiotics, analgesics, and a strict watch on the vitals and general state of the patient. In 90% of the patients, the mass resolves without complications.

After conservative management, a CT scan follow-up should be done to check for complete resolution of the mass. Following successful management of appendicular mass, removal of the appendix is advised by interval appendectomy in 6-8 weeks.

Other options:
Option A: Emergency appendectomy is the treatment of choice for acute appendicitis without an appendicular mass. However, due to the reasons discussed above (localized inflammation and difficult surgery), surgical intervention for an appendicular mass is reserved for worsening patient vitals, increasing or spreading abdominal pain, or increasing size of the mass.

Drainage of an abscess may be required. However, open surgical drainage (Option B) is not preferred, and radiologically guided drainage is the preferred method. 

Option D: Oral antibiotics and outpatient follow-up are not recommended due to the chances of the patient worsening, and the continued need for monitoring patient vitals and the size of the appendicular mass.

Related Pearl: Oshner Sherren Regimen

Principle :

  • The inflammatory process is already localised and that inadvertent surgery is difficult and may be dangerous.
  • It may be impossible to find the appendix and, occasionally, a faecal fistula may form.
  • Antibiotic therapy should be given after performing CECT abdomen
  • Abscess if present can be drained radiologically.

Outcome :

  • Improvement in 24–48 h
  • 90% cases resolve
  • Failure should raise suspicion of Crohn’s disease and carcinoma. 

Criteria for stopping conservative treatment of Appendicular mass:

  • Rising pulse rate
  • Increasing or spreading abdominal pain
  • Increasing size of the mass

questions.text: A 4-week-old male infant presents with complaints of non-bilious vomiting for the past 2 days. Examination reveals a lethargic infant with signs of dehydration, and an associated firm and mobile mass in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen just beneath the liver edge. Which of the following is the definitive management for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a 4-week-old male infant presenting with non-bilious vomiting, lethargy, and signs of dehydration, with an associated firm and mobile mass in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen just beneath the liver edge is suggestive of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. The definitive management for this condition is the Ramstedt procedure involving a pyloromyotomy.

Pyloric stenosis presents with non-bilious, projectile vomiting starting between 2 and 6 weeks of age. As vomiting continues, it worsens in frequency and forcefulness, resulting in a progressive loss of fluid, hydrogen ions, and chloride, leading to dehydration and hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.

A characteristic feature aiding diagnosis is the presence of an abdominal mass, usually just below the liver edge. The mass is firm, movable, approximately 2 cm in length, and described as 'olive-shaped.' The mass is best palpated after an episode of vomiting. After feeding, there may be a visible gastric peristaltic wave that progresses across the abdomen. 

Ultrasound examination confirms the diagnosis in the majority of cases. Criteria for diagnosis include a pyloric thickness of 3-4 mm, an overall pyloric length of 15-19 mm, and a pyloric diameter of 10-14 mm. USG may show the characteristic cervix sign and nipple sign.

Treatment includes correcting the metabolic abnormality preoperatively and the standard surgical procedure done for definitive management is Ramstedt pyloromyotomy. It may be performed laparoscopically or through a supraumbilical or right upper quadrant incision.


Other options
Option A: Swenson procedure is a surgical procedure done for Hirschsprung disease.

Option C: Kasai's procedure (Hepatoportoenterostomy) is performed in the management of biliary atresia.

Option D: Bishop-Koop Anastomosis and Mikulicz enterostomy are done for meconium ileus.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child presents with complaints of intermittent abdominal pain and vomiting for the past 1 day. Examination reveals a firm, tender, and slightly curved longitudinal mass in the right upper abdomen, which increases in size during the episodes of abdominal pain. Radiological imaging on a contrast enema is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a 2-year-old male child with complaints of intermittent abdominal pain, vomiting, and a firm, tender, and slightly curved longitudinal mass ("sausage-shaped") in the right upper abdomen is suggestive of intussusception. The radiological image showing the characteristic coiled spring appearance (barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space) is also suggestive of the same.

Intussusception occurs when a portion of the alimentary tract is telescoped into an adjacent segment. It is the most common cause of intestinal obstruction between 5 months and 3 years of age. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. 

The combination of paroxysmal abdominal pain, vomiting, and a palpable abdominal mass is a highly characteristic clinical presentation; the presence
of associated rectal bleeding invariably confirms the diagnosis. Palpation of the abdomen usually reveals a slightly tender, "sausage-shaped" mass, sometimes ill-defined, which might increase in size during an episode of pain and is most often in the right upper abdomen, with its longitudinal axis cephalocaudal. However, approximately 30% of patients do not have a palpable mass.

USG abdomen is useful to confirm the diagnosis. The findings include:

  • Target sign/ doughnut sign/ bull's eye sign
  • Pseudo kidney sign
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

Barium contrast enemas demonstrate a filling defect or cupping in the head of the contrast media where its advance is obstructed by the intussusceptum. This is known as the claw sign (shown below). A central linear column of contrast media may be visible in the compressed lumen of the intussusceptum, and a thin rim of contrast may be seen trapped around the invaginating intestine in the folds of mucosa within the intussuscipiens (coiled-spring sign).

Other options
Option A: Acute gastroenteritis is an important differential especially if a child presents without a mass. The bloody stools and abdominal cramps that accompany enterocolitis are less severe and less regular, and the infant is recognizably ill between pains. The characteristic abdominal mass seen in this patient is highly suggestive of intussusception. 

Option B: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis can also present with an upper abdominal mass. However, the mass is characteristically described as "olive-shaped" instead of longitudinal and sausage-like as described here and usually presents in the first few weeks of life. Radiological imaging is also suggestive of intussusception.

Option C: Necrotizing enterocolitis is a common cause of acute abdomen in premature infants. It is unlikely to be the cause of abdominal pain and an associated mass, as seen in this case.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with chief complaints of abdominal pain with an associated abdominal mass after a severe bout of coughing. He has a history of chronic bronchitis and atrial fibrillation and is on oral anticoagulants. Abdominal examination reveals an ill-defined mass in the right lower quadrant with increasing pain on tensing the abdominal muscles. Which of the following clinical signs do you expect to find in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a 60-year-old male who presents with abdominal pain and a right lower quadrant mass with increasing pain on tensing the abdominal muscles is suggestive of a rectus sheath hematoma. Chronic pulmonary disease (eg, chronic bronchitis) resulting in coughing fits and a history of anticoagulant use are important risk factors for the development of this condition. A characteristic clinical sign is the palpation findings do not change during contraction of the rectus muscle and the mass becomes fixed, known as Fothergill’s sign.

A rectus sheath hematoma arises from a disruption of one of the branches of the inferior epigastric artery. This is more common in older patients with a history of anticoagulant use due to weakness of the rectus sheath to tamponade the hemorrhage. Trauma to the abdominal wall, including iatrogenic trauma can also lead to the disruption of the vessel and a hematoma formation. 

It usually presents with abdominal pain and a tender lower abdominal mass. The pain increases on tensing the abdominal muscles. The Fothergill’s sign is said to be present if a mass remains palpable and becomes fixed when the rectus muscles are contracted.

Ultrasound or CT scan with intravenous contrast are useful in diagnosis. The management depends on the hemodynamic stability of the patient and ranges from conservative management and observation for stable patients to angiographic embolization or surgical intervention for those presenting with hemodynamic instability.

Other options
Option A: Ransohoff's sign is the yellow discoloration of the umbilical region seen in a ruptured common bile duct.

Option C: Blumberg's sign is the transient abdominal wall rebound tenderness associated with peritoneal inflammation.

Option D: Aaron’s sign is pain or pressure in the epigastrium or anterior chest with persistent firm pressure applied to the Mcburney point seen in acute appendicitis.

Related Pearl: Abdominal examination signs

Sign Explanation Diagnosis
Aaron sign Pain or pressure in the epigastric or anterior chest with persistent firm pressure applied to Mcburney point  Acute appendicitis
Bassler sign Sharp pain created by compressing appendix between the abdominal wall and iliacus Chronic appendicitis
Ten Horn sign Pain caused by gentle traction of right testicle Acute appendicitis
Blumberg's sign Transient abdominal wall rebound tenderness Peritoneal inflammation
Chandelier sign Extreme lower abdominal pain with movement of the cervix Pelvic inflammatory disease
Courvoisier's sign Palpable gallbladder in presence of painless jaundice Periampullary tumor
Cruveilhier sign Varicose veins at the umbilicus (caput-medusae) Portal hypertension
Fothergill's sign Abdominal wall mass that does not cross the midline and remains palpable when rectus contracted  Rectus muscle hematomas
Ransohoff sign Yellow discoloration of umbilical region  Ruptured CBD

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient who has recently been diagnosed with diabetes presents with complaints of upper abdominal discomfort, anorexia, and jaundice for the past 1 month. Abdominal examination reveals a soft, globular mass in the right upper quadrant, just below the liver edge. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 65-year-old male presenting with upper abdominal discomfort, anorexia, jaundice, and a palpable gallbladder known as the Courvoisier's sign (soft, globular mass in the right upper quadrant that moves with respiration) is highly suggestive of pancreatic adenocarcinoma. An elderly patient with recently diagnosed diabetes presenting with the above symptoms should raise suspicion for the same.

Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinomas arise most commonly in the head of the gland. This usually presents with jaundice. Courvoisier's law states that in the presence of a painless, palpable, enlarged gallbladder and mild jaundice, the cause is unlikely to be gallstones because the common bile duct obstruction by gallstones would lead to a shrunken fibrotic gallbladder. The gallbladder is enlarged in conditions causing a slow occlusion, as in tumors surrounding the distal common bile duct, which implicates possible cancer of the head of the pancreas.

The exceptions to the Courvoisier's law include:

  • Double impacted stones (stones in both the cystic duct and the distal common bile duct)
  • Primary CBD stone
  • Oriental cholangiohepatitis 
  • Mirizzi's syndrome

Other options
Option A: Cholelithiasis or gallstones are unlikely to be associated with a palpable gallbladder, as stated above, due to an associated shrunken and fibrotic gallbladder.

Option B: Chronic cholecystitis would be associated with chronic irritation and inflammation of the gallbladder wall and would also result in a shrunken gallbladder.

Option D: Hepatocellular carcinoma can also present with upper abdominal discomfort, anorexia, and jaundice. However, it will not be associated with a palpable gallbladder. Rather, it causes tender hepatomegaly.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with complaints of chronic cough, weight loss, and evening rise of temperature. On examination, there is a palpable, ill-defined mass in the right iliac fossa and a doughy consistency of the abdomen prompting a suspicion of intestinal tuberculosis. Which of the following is the most likely site involved in this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 35-year-old female patient presenting with chronic cough, weight loss, evening rise of temperature, and examination revealing an ill-defined mass in the right iliac fossa with a 'doughy' consistency of the abdomen is highly suggestive of intestinal tuberculosis. The most common sites of involvement in this condition are the distal ileum and caecum.

Intestinal tuberculosis can be caused by the swallowing of infected sputum in a patient with pulmonary tuberculosis, drinking infected unpasteurized milk, or by a hematogenous spread from the primary site. There are two types: ulcerative and hyperplastic. Both types may be associated with marked mesenteric lymphadenopathy.

The hyperplastic type is characterized by a marked inflammatory reaction causing hyperplasia and thickening of the terminal ileum because of its abundance of lymphoid follicles. Patients usually present with weight loss, chronic cough, malaise, evening rise in temperature, alternating constipation and diarrhea, and intermittent abdominal pain with distension. Ileocaecal tuberculosis may present with a right iliac fossa mass and features of intestinal obstruction. The patient looks chronically ill, and the abdomen may have a 'doughy' feel due to areas of localized ascites.

Important differentials for a right iliac fossa mass include an appendicular mass, lymphoma, carcinoma of the caecum, Crohn's disease, tuberculosis, or actinomycosis. A barium follow-through or small bowel enema in intestinal tuberculosis will show a long, narrow filling defect in the terminal ileum (string sign) with a shrunken and pulled-up cecum. CT will also demonstrate the narrowed segment with proximal distension and the associated lymphadenopathy. When a patient presents without features of obstruction, antituberculous medication is advised and may be curative. When signs of obstruction are present, surgical intervention in the form of ileocaecal resection is often required.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presents with complaints of painless hematuria for the past 1 month. Examination reveals a right flank mass, that is firm, non-tender, and moves with respiration. There is an associated non-reducing, right-sided varicocele. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of an elderly male presenting with painless hematuria, right renal mass (firm, non-tender, right flank mass that moves with respiration), and an associated non-reducing, right-sided varicocele is suggestive of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). The investigation of choice for diagnosis and staging of RCC is a triphasic CECT abdomen.

RCC is the most common malignant tumor of the kidney that usually presents in the elderly. Cigarette smoking and hypertension are major associated risk factors. The classic triad of presentation is with flank pain, macroscopic haematuria, and a palpable flank mass. Advanced cases can also present with bilateral lower limb edema or a non-reducing, right-sided varicocele owing to a thrombus in the IVC.

Triphasic contrast-enhanced CT is the investigation of choice for RCC (image given below). On CT, small lesions enhance homogeneously, whereas larger lesions have irregular enhancement due to areas of necrosis. The CT also provides additional information on the function of the opposite kidney, primary tumor extension, venous involvement, enlargement of regional lymph nodes, the status of the adrenal glands, and intra-abdominal metastatic disease. Contrast-enhanced MRI is the investigation of choice for detecting vascular invasion of RCC.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with an enlarging abdominal mass at the site of previous trauma for the past 1 month. The mass is firm and non-tender. After initial imaging, a core needle biopsy reveals the following histological findings. Which of the following conditions is associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 35-year-old female patient presenting with an enlarging, firm, and non-tender abdominal mass and histological findings of long spindle cells in a collagenous stroma are suggestive of desmoid tumor. These tumors are associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

Desmoid tumors (also known as aggressive fibromatosis) are fibroblastic neoplasms with aggressive infiltrative behavior but no metastatic potential. 10% to 15% of patients with FAP develop desmoid tumors. The risk is even greater for patients with Gardner's syndrome. Risk factors for sporadic disease include previous surgical incision, pregnancy, hormonal exposure, and trauma. They occur more commonly in females. 

These tumors can occur anywhere in the body but are most common in the abdomen and abdominal wall. They present as firm, painful, or non-painful masses, which may be either slow or rapidly growing. 

The investigation of choice is MRI. Histopathological diagnosis is done by a core-needle or incisional biopsy. Management involves observation for stable, asymptomatic, or recurrent desmoids. Surgery is indicated for patients with symptomatic disease, risk of invasion, or enlarging tumors.

Other options:

Option A: von Hippel–Lindau syndrome is associated with renal cell carcinoma, hemangioblastomas of the retina and central nervous system, and pheochromocytoma.

Option C: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is associated with gastrointestinal carcinomas, breast cancer, testicular cancer, pancreatic cancer, and benign pigmentation of the skin and mucosa.

Option D: Cowden syndrome is associated with cancer of the breast, endometrium, and thyroid.

Related Pearl: Desmoid tumor

  • Unencapsulated fibroma arising from musculoaponeurotic structures usually below the umbilicus.
  • Females>males
  • Extraabdominal (65%) > abdominal (25%) > intraabdominal (15%)
  • Associated with FAP (Gardner syndrome)
  • Infiltrates surrounding tissues but no metastasis and no sarcomatous change.
  • Investigation of choice – MRI
  • Treatment:
    • Wide local excision with negative margin
    • More prone for recurrence – treated by surgery and radiotherapy

questions.text:
A 14-year-old patient presents with complaints of fever, myalgias, and a sore throat for the past 1 week. Examination reveals a palpable left upper quadrant abdominal mass, which is smooth, firm, and with a notch on the medial surface. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?

HHV - Human herpesvirus
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an adolescent presenting with fever, myalgias, sore throat, and splenomegaly (a palpable left upper quadrant abdominal mass, which is smooth, firm, and with a characteristic notch on the medial surface) is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis (IM). The causative agent behind the condition is HHV-4 (Epstein-Barr virus).

IM most commonly presents in adolescents with initial symptoms of fever, sore throat, fatigue, myalgia, and malaise. Pharyngitis is often the most prominent sign, with the enlargement of the tonsils and an exudate resembling that of streptococcal pharyngitis. It can be associated with tender, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. 

Splenomegaly most commonly occurs during the second and third week after initial symptoms. The spleen enlarges from under the left costal margin down and medially toward the umbilicus. A characteristic notch on the medial surface helps differentiate it from an enlarged left kidney. The mass is firm, smooth, regular in shape, and moves with respiration.

Laboratory investigations in IM demonstrate an elevated white blood cell count with lymphocytosis and >10% atypical lymphocytes. The diagnostic test for this condition is the Paul Bunnell test, a heterophile antibody reaction test. In IM, heterophile antibodies can usually be demonstrated by the end of the first week of illness.

Most cases are self-limiting. However, splenic rupture is a rare but possible complication due to the associated splenomegaly. It is a potentially fatal condition, and patients are thus advised to avoid contact sports for at least 4 weeks from diagnosis.

Other options:
Option A: HHV-1 or the herpes simplex virus type 1 causes oral and/ or genital herpes (mainly orofacial).

Option B: HHV-3 or the varicella-zoster virus causes chickenpox and shingles.

Option C: HHV-6 or the human B-cell lymphotropic virus causes roseola infantum or exanthema subitum.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with abdominal distension, pain, and periorbital ecchymoses. On examination, a large, non-tender, firm, and irregular mass is palpated crossing the midline. The amplification of which of the following oncogenes is associated with a poor prognosis in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 2-year-old child with abdominal distension, pain, periorbital ecchymoses, and a large, non-tender, firm, and irregular abdominal mass crossing the midline is suggestive of neuroblastoma. Amplification of MYCN (N-myc) proto-oncogene is associated with a poor prognosis in this condition.

Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor in children. It is derived from primordial neural crest cells. It most commonly arises from the adrenal glands, followed by sites along the sympathetic chain, such as the paravertebral region of the abdomen and posterior mediastinum.

When they originate from the adrenals, these tumors present with abdominal distension and pain. The associated abdominal mass is large, irregular, and crosses the midline in the majority of cases. Metastatic disease can cause fever, irritability, failure to thrive, bone pain, cytopenias, bluish subcutaneous nodules, orbital proptosis, and periorbital ecchymoses.

CT or MRI are useful in evaluating the mass, which often shows areas of calcification and hemorrhage. Tumor markers such as homovanillic acid (HVA) and vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) are elevated in the urine of the majority of patients and help to confirm the diagnosis. A biopsy of the tumor reveals the presence of small round blue cells with Homer-Wright pseudorosettes (shown below). 

Other options:

Option A: Bcl-2 amplification is associated with follicular lymphoma and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

Option C: c-KIT amplification is associated with gastrointestinal stromal tumors and mastocytosis.

Option D: KRAS mutation can result in colon, lung, and pancreatic tumors.

questions.text: A newborn male is found to have a left-sided flank mass. Ultrasound abdomen reveals left grade 4 hydronephrosis. The right kidney appears normal. What is the likely underlying cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a newborn male presenting with a left renal mass with associated grade 4 hydronephrosis on ultrasound likely has ureteropelvic junction obstruction.

The most common cause of an abdominal mass in newborns is hydronephrosis due to congenital pelviureteric junction obstruction (PUJO). PUJO is more common in males and occurs more frequently on the left side. 

Most cases of PUJO with associated hydronephrosis are now detected before birth with antenatal ultrasound. If undetected, it presents in infancy as a palpable renal mass. Associated presentations include abdominal or flank pain, febrile UTI, or hematuria after minimal trauma.

Ultrasound abdomen is useful to grade the severity and persistence of hydronephrosis which in turn guides management. Mild cases with grade 1 or 2 hydronephrosis and normal renal parenchyma are managed with observation and subsequent renal ultrasound studies to monitor the severity.

However, most cases present with grade 3 or 4 hydronephrosis in which spontaneous resolution is less likely. These cases require a surgical correction in which the stenotic segment is excised, and the normal ureter and renal pelvis are reattached. This procedure is known as a pyeloplasty. 

Other options:
Option A: Retrocaval ureter is an anomaly in which the upper right ureter travels posterior to the inferior vena cava. This may also cause unilateral hydronephrosis, although this is much more frequent on the right side. Ultrasound reveals the classic sign of a dilated upper ureter associated with hydronephrosis. 

Option B: Midureteral valve can also be associated with unilateral hydronephrosis. However, this condition is very rare.

Option D: Posterior urethral valves are the most common cause of severe obstructive uropathy in children. However, they would be associated with bilateral hydronephrosis and a distended bladder.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presents to the emergency with lower abdominal pain, inability to pass urine, and a palpable and tender suprapubic mass. He has a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Initial catheterization attempts have failed. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Placement of a small (12F to 14F) Foley catheter
CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly male presenting with lower abdominal pain, inability to pass urine, and a palpable and tender suprapubic mass (palpable bladder) is suggestive of acute urinary retention. Given the history of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and a failed initial catheterization, the best next step in the management of this patient is the placement of a coude catheter.

Acute urinary retention most commonly occurs in men with BPH. Other causes include diabetic neuropathy, urethral stricture, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson’s disease, or the use of opiates or anticholinergics. It is the most commonly encountered urologic emergency. Patients usually present with an inability to pass urine, severe suprapubic pain, and a distended, palpable, and tender bladder (as shown below). 

An ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis can be helpful in cases of diagnostic uncertainty. Treatment includes the placement of a urethral catheter as quickly as possible. However, BPH or urethral strictures often make the placement of a catheter difficult.

For men with BPH, a coude (curved) catheter helps negotiate past the angulation in the prostatic urethra. Coude-tip catheters have a slight bend just before the tip. This curved tip allows them to be maneuvered beyond obstructions in the bulbar and prostatic urethra. They carry less risk of urethral trauma compared to straight-tip catheters. The alternative to this is a larger Foley catheter (18F to 20F), which is less flexible and is more likely to push into the bladder beyond the obstruction. 

The algorithm below describes management of a difficult catheterization: 

Other options:

Option B: Placement of a small (12F to 14F) Foley catheter is not indicated as they are more flexible and more likely to curl in the prostatic urethra. A larger catheter is preferred to push through the obstruction. Smaller catheters are used for bypassing a urethral stricture.

Option C: Suprapubic catheterization is an option if the above attempts to catheterize the bladder fail. However, it is not the initial step in managing acute urinary retention.

Option D: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is not indicated. Acute urinary retention is an urologic emergency and requires urgent catheterization. A bedside ultrasound may be done for diagnostic uncertainty.

questions.text: A 4-year-old female child presents with episodic abdominal pain, jaundice, and a palpable mass in the right hypochondrium. Abdominal ultrasound reveals a cystic structure arising from the biliary tree. Which of the following is unlikely to be a complication of this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of a 4-year-old female child presenting with episodic abdominal pain, jaundice, a palpable mass in the right hypochondrium, and ultrasound findings of a cystic structure arising from the biliary tree is characteristic of a choledochal cyst. Of the listed options, intestinal obstruction is an unlikely complication of choledochal cysts.

Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic biliary tree. They are 4 times more common in females. They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable right upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain. However, they may remain minimally symptomatic and may escape detection.

If left undiagnosed, choledochal cysts can present with the following complications:

  • Ascending cholangitis (recurrent attacks may lead to cirrhosis and portal hypertension) 
  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Bile peritonitis (due to cyst rupture) 
  • Malignant transformation into a cholangiocarcinoma

Diagnostic investigations include an ultrasound abdomen, which may reveal a cystic structure arising from the biliary tree. Along with a CT, it helps demonstrate the dimensions of the cyst, its relationship to the vascular structures, and the intrahepatic ductal configuration. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is the investigation of choice and may provide a more detailed depiction of the anatomy of the cyst. Management depends on the type of cyst according to the Todani classification. 

Todani classification of the choledochal cysts along with their management is as shown below~

Type of choledochal cyst Surgical management
Type I -  fusiform dilatation of the bile duct (most common - seen in 75% of patients) Complete surgical excision, cholecystectomy, and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy
Type II - saccular diverticulum from the common bile duct Diverticulectomy, cholecystectomy, and common bile duct repair
Type III- diverticulum within the pancreas, also known as choledochoceles ERCP + sphincterotomy (Only cyst in which reconstruction is not required)
Type IV a - multiple cysts (both intrahepatic and extrahepatic) Liver transplant
b - multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree Kasai procedure (portoenterostomy)
Type V - multiple cysts involving only intrahepatic ducts (Caroli's disease) Liver transplant

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient with an abdominal mass was diagnosed with gestational trophoblastic neoplasia. On further evaluation, it is found that neoplasia has metastasized to the liver and lungs. What would be the clinical staging according to FIGO classification?
questions.solution:
The patient would be classified to have stage-IV gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN).

International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) Staging for GTN is as follows:

  • Stage I - Confined to the uterus
  • Stage II - GTN extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structures
  • Stage III - GTN extends to the lungs, with or without known genital tract involvement
  • Stage IV - All other metastatic sites.

This patient with metastasis to the liver and lungs has Stage IV disease.

GTN includes tumors that cause aggressive invasion of the endometrium and myometrium by trophoblastic cells. This includes invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumor, and epithelioid trophoblastic tumor. GTN is diagnosed based on elevated β-hCG levels. Criteria for diagnosis of GTN:

  • Persistence of β-hCG level plateau in 4 measurements for 3 weeks or longer
  • Rise in β-hCG levels in 3 or more consecutive measurements done weekly, over a period of 2 weeks or longer
  • Elevated β-hCG level for 6 months or more
  • Histologic diagnosis of choriocarcinoma.

A modified prognostic scoring system by the WHO distinguishes patients at low risk for therapeutic failure from those at high risk. Treatment for the low-risk disease is chemotherapy with methotrexate, while those with high-risk disease are treated with etoposide, methotrexate, and dactinomycin alternating with cyclophosphamide and vincristine (EMA/CO) chemotherapy.

Related Pearl: Risk factors and FIGO staging of Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia

Risk factors

  • Older age
  • β-hCG levels > 100,000 mIU/mL
  • Uterine size that is large-forgestational age
  • Theca-lutein cysts > 6 cm
  • Slow decline in β-hCG levels
  • Postevacuation uterine sonographic surveillance showing myometrial nodules or hypervascularity may be a predictor of subsequent neoplasia.

FIGO staging:

Stage I Disease confined to the uterus
Stage II GTD extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structure
Stage III Lung metastasis with or without genital tract involvement
Stage IV Other metastasis

questions.text: A middle-aged man who presented with an abdominal mass has the following subcutaneous venous circulation with the direction of the flow as depicted by the arrows in the image. This can be seen in:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the upward flow of subcutaneous venous circulation can be seen in inferior vena cava obstruction.

The level of the umbilicus is a watershed area for venous and lymphatic circulation. The systemic veins anastomose with tributaries of portal veins at the umbilicus. Normally, venous blood and lymphatics flow upwards above the plane of the umbilicus and downwards below this plane. 

  • In inferior vena cava obstruction, the blood flow in the veins of the anterior abdominal wall is completely upward.
  • In superior vena cava obstruction, the blood flow in the veins of the anterior abdominal veins is completely downward.
  • In portal hypertension with dilated abdominal veins, the blood flow is away from the umbilicus, radiating like a star from the umbilicus (caput-medusae).

Causes of superior and inferior vena caval obstruction:

Causes of SVC obstruction Causes of IVC obstruction 

 

1. Mediastinal malignancy

2. Mediastinal fibrosis

3. Retrosternal thyroid

4. Aortic aneurysm

5. Radiation fibrosis

6. Iatrogenic
  1.  Thrombosis extension
  2.  Tumor invasion
  3.  Extrinsic compression (Eg: Pregnancy, abdominal mass)
  4. Coagulopathy
  5. Sepsis, dehydration, immobility
  6. Iatrogenic

Splenic vein thrombosis is one of the prehepatic causes of portal hypertension, in which the portal venous system is affected before it enters the liver.

questions.text: A young nulliparous female who desires pregnancy comes to you with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding. On palpation, an abdominal mass corresponding to 14 weeks of gestation is felt. The mass is found to be a subserosal pedunculated fibroid on imaging. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice in this nulliparous female with subserosal pedunculated fibroid is myomectomy. Myomectomy is indicated if the uterus size corresponds to more than 12 weeks of gestation and the patient desires pregnancy.

Myomectomy refers to the removal of fibroids and preserving the uterus. It is indicated in fibroids which present with the following 

  • Persistent uterine bleeding despite medical therapy
  • Excessive pain or pressure symptoms
  • Size > 12 weeks, patient desirous to have a baby
  • Unexplained infertility with distortion of the uterine cavity due to fibroid
  • Recurrent pregnancy wastage due to fibroid
  • Rapid growth during follow up
  • Subserous pedunculated fibroid

Myomectomy can be performed by laparoscopy, hysteroscopy, or laparotomy. It is contraindicated in patients with an infected fibroid, pelvic or endometrial tuberculosis, suspected malignancy, and growth in post-menopausal and multiparous women where hysterectomy can be the safe definitive management.

Fibroids are benign estrogen dependant tumors of the uterine smooth muscles and connective tissue. 

Management of uterine fibroids in asymptomatic patients includes observation with regular follow-up regardless of the size of the fibroid. Surgery is indicated in cornual fibroids if it causes infertility or pedunculated fibroids (due to the risk of torsion). 

In symptomatic patients, medical therapy is done to shrink the fibroid. It acts as a preoperative adjunct. Surgical methods such as myomectomy, laparoscopic myolysis, hysterectomy, and endometrial ablation are tried for patients with persistent symptoms despite conservative management. Hysterectomy is done in postmenopausal women and in multiparous women who have completed their families or are not desirous of childbirth.

Related Pearl: Myomectomy

Myomectomy

  • Retains uterus and hence preserves childbearing function.
  • Effective for heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure.
  • Disadvantage - formation of new clones of abnormal myocytes.
  • Hysteroscopic myomectomy is the procedure of choice for removing intracavitary myomas.
  • Vaginal myomectomy is performed in case, a fibroid prolapses through the cervix.

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency with petechiae, bruising, and abdominal distension. Examination revealed an abdominal mass.  Investigations revealed schistocytes and thrombocytopenia. What is the most probable cause of the mass?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with petechiae, and abdominal distension with schistocytes and thrombocytopenia. This in child most likely has Kasabach-Merritt syndrome (secondary DIC). His abdominal mass is likely to be a hepatic hemangioma. 

Kasabach-Merritt syndrome is a life-threatening complication that occurs in patients with giant hemangiomas. It is most commonly seen in infants. 

Clinical features: 

  • Enlarged abdomen
  • Hepatomegaly or jaundice
  • Petechiae, bruising, and frank bleeding
  • Painful lesions
  • Anemia

It is characterized by profound thrombocytopenia and consumptive coagulopathy leading to a DIC-like picture.

Other options: 

Option A: Neuroblastomas are tumors of the sympathetic ganglia and adrenal medulla that are derived from primordial neural crest cells. It is the most common extracranial solid tumor of childhood and the most frequently diagnosed tumor in infancy. Brain tumors are the most common solid tumors in childhood. They present as a flank mass that crosses the midline.

Option B: Hepatoblastoma is the most common childhood liver tumor. Histologically it is composed of small polygonal embryonal cells forming trabeculae, acini, or papillary structures in the developing liver.

Option C: Wilms tumor is the most common primary malignant renal tumor in children and is the second most common malignant abdominal tumor in children. The clinical presentation usually involves an asymptomatic unilateral abdominal mass, hypertension, abdominal pain, and gross painless hematuria. Constitutional symptoms of fever, anorexia, and weight loss can also be present at the time of diagnosis.
